entries.title: Record temps send Chicagoans outdoors — and to car wash lines
entries.summary: <p>The temperature hits a record high in February, and where’s your first stop?</p><p>The obvious answer: The car wash.</p><p>People all over Chicago used Monday’s warm weather to turn their cars from salty reminders of winter to shiny and spring-ready vehicles. Then, many took a nice drive with the windows rolled down.</p><div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="Enhancement-item" data-crop=""> <figure class="Figure"><a class="AnchorLink" id="image-f10000" name="image-f10000"></a> <picture data-crop="medium"> <source type="image/webp" width="490" height="275" data-srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/1d38703/2147483647/strip/true/crop/6122x3436+0+324/resize/490x275!/format/webp/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F76%2F24%2Fde59b0464dd08186637321bd3033%2Fweather-260217-01.JPG 1x,https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/737995e/2147483647/strip/true/crop/6122x3436+0+324/resize/980x550!/format/webp/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F76%2F24%2Fde59b0464dd08186637321bd3033%2Fweather-260217-01.JPG 2x" data-lazy-load="true" srcset="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" /> <source width="490" height="275" data-srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/a3fc872/2147483647/strip/true/crop/6122x3436+0+324/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F76%2F24%2Fde59b0464dd08186637321bd3033%2Fweather-260217-01.JPG" data-lazy-load="true" srcset="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" /> <img class="Image" alt="A woman runs with her dog in Humboldt Park on Monday. " srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/a3fc872/2147483647/strip/true/crop/6122x3436+0+324/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F76%2F24%2Fde59b0464dd08186637321bd3033%2Fweather-260217-01.JPG 1x,https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/fcddc27/2147483647/strip/true/crop/6122x3436+0+324/resize/980x550!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F76%2F24%2Fde59b0464dd08186637321bd3033%2Fweather-260217-01.JPG 2x" width="490" height="275" data-src="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/a3fc872/2147483647/strip/true/crop/6122x3436+0+324/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F76%2F24%2Fde59b0464dd08186637321bd3033%2Fweather-260217-01.JPG" data-lazy-load="true" src="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" > </picture> <div class="Figure-content"><figcaption class="Figure-caption"><p>A woman runs with her dog in Humboldt Park on Monday. The Chicago area set a daily record for Feb. 16, with the high reaching 65 at O’Hare Airport. The previous record high was 58 in 1921.</p></figcaption><span class="line"></span><div class="Figure-credit"><p>Anthony Vazquez</p></div></div> </figure> </div> </div><p></p><p>“It’s a vacation day,” Denise Cameron said of the unseasonably warm Presidents Day as she waited for her car at Bert’s Car Wash in West Town. “Everything’s nice — when your car is cleaned and your house is cleaned, everything is good.”</p><p>Another customer — dashing to her freshly detailed car — said she hadn’t gotten it washed since the first snow in the fall.</p><p>The start of this week is giving the city a short reprieve from a snowy and cold winter that saw a 20-day stretch of subfreezing temperatures — the longest in almost two decades — and several snowstorms.</p><div class="Enhancement" data-align-center><div class="Enhancement-item"> <div class="ExternalContent-wrapper" > <div class="TweetUrl"> <blockquote class="twitter-tweet"><p lang="en" dir="ltr">Spring-like warmth will carry occasional opportunities for showers and even a thunderstorm through the middle of the week. Reality will return toward the end of the week as a cold front delivers more seasonable temperatures (especially by the weekend). <a href="https://twitter.com/hashtag/ILwx?src=hash&ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw">#ILwx</a> <a href="https://twitter.com/hashtag/INwx?src=hash&ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw">#INwx</a> <a href="https://t.co/3mqylyavvB">pic.twitter.com/3mqylyavvB</a></p>— NWS Chicago (@NWSChicago) <a href="https://twitter.com/NWSChicago/status/2023491551679201402?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw">February 16, 2026</a></blockquote> <script async src="https://platform.twitter.com/widgets.js" charset="utf-8"></script> </div> </div> </div></div><p>After a couple sunny and mild days over the weekend, Monday hit a high of 65, making it the warmest Feb. 16 in the city’s recorded history, according to National Weather Service data. The previous record had stood since 1921 at 58 degrees</p><div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="Enhancement-item" data-crop=""> <figure class="Figure"><a class="AnchorLink" id="image-230000" name="image-230000"></a> <picture data-crop="medium"> <source type="image/webp" width="490" height="275" srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/4578016/2147483647/strip/true/crop/6122x3436+0+324/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F9e%2F4a%2F8ed5a31c410e830eb3ad5956b55b%2Fweather-260217-03.JPG 1x,https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/3cbd62e/2147483647/strip/true/crop/6122x3436+0+324/resize/980x550!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F9e%2F4a%2F8ed5a31c410e830eb3ad5956b55b%2Fweather-260217-03.JPG 2x" width="490" height="275" data-src="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/4578016/2147483647/strip/true/crop/6122x3436+0+324/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F9e%2F4a%2F8ed5a31c410e830eb3ad5956b55b%2Fweather-260217-03.JPG" data-lazy-load="true" src="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" > </picture> <div class="Figure-content"><figcaption class="Figure-caption"><p>A bicyclist rides on Milwaukee Avenue on Monday.</p></figcaption><span class="line"></span><div class="Figure-credit"><p>Anthony Vazquez/Sun-Times</p></div></div> </figure> </div> </div><p>With so many people having the same idea, drivers had to wait in long lines to get their cars cleaned. As many as 19 cars were in line at Bert’s — including two Chicago police vehicles — stretching down the block and around the corner.</p><h3>Perfect winter for car washes</h3><p>Bert’s co-owner Jorge Aguilar said the wait on busy days can last more than an hour. </p><p>“We’ve been busy the last three weeks, nonstop,” Aguilar said. “This year, the wintertime was a little different, right? We haven't seen this winter for many, many years. They got the snow, they got the cold, and then they got warm weather. For us, it was the perfect winter.”</p><p>Aguilar said about 300 cars have been going through Bert’s every day, with 14 or 15 workers on the clock to meet demand.</p><p>Other car washes had lines at least a dozen deep.</p><p>The warm weather and the school holiday brought many outdoors in shorts and short sleeves, grilling and having fun at the lakefront.</p><p>“It's been widespread in the area with temperatures more like mid-April than mid-February,” said Brett Borchardt, a senior meteorologist with the National Weather Service.</p><p>The high of 65 degrees at O’Hare Airport set a record. Borchardt said Peru, Ill., about 100 miles southwest of the city, hit 70 degrees.</p><p>Chicagoans muttered and moaned through cold, wind and snow since October after a series of mild winters the past few years.</p><p>The city exceeded the entire 2024-25 snowfall total by the end of December and has seen 32.1 inches to this point.</p><p>And the 20 days from Jan. 17 to Feb. 6, when temperatures didn’t rise above freezing, made for the longest such stretch in Chicago since 2007.</p><h3>Getting active in Humboldt Park</h3><p>In Humboldt Park on the West Side, Karl Wenzel and Charles Hekma shed their shirts for some tennis, something they haven’t been able to do since the fall.</p><div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="Enhancement-item" data-crop=""> <figure class="Figure"><a class="AnchorLink" id="image-6e0000" name="image-6e0000"></a> <picture data-crop="medium"> <source type="image/webp" width="490" height="275" class="Figure-content"><figcaption class="Figure-caption"><p>Charles Hekma and a buddy play tennis for the first time since fall on Monday at Humboldt Park.The winds posed a bit of a challenge.</p></figcaption><span class="line"></span><div class="Figure-credit"><p>Anthony Vazquez/Sun-Times</p></div></div> </figure> </div> </div><p>“It’s windy, which is difficult to play a little bit, but it’s great,” Hekma said. “Got to take advantage, go outside.”</p><p>Wenzel said it was nice to see people getting active.</p><p>“Feels more like a spring day rather than a winter day for sure,” he said. “We’re able to play shirtless in February. That is unusual. I don’t think I’ve ever been able to say that before. I keep forgetting it’s February, actually.”</p><p>Across the street, Gary Times was playing fetch with his two small dogs, Vito and Cupcake.</p><p>“Sweet relief. Finally,” Times said. “I’m tired of the winter.</p><p>“They’ve been cooped up in the house for a little bit,” he said of his dogs. “I don’t really like bringing them out when it’s really cold. So they’ve kind of been whimpering a bit lately since they can’t go outside. But they’ve been having a good time.”</p><p>Nearby, Reynaldo Rodriguez, a local artist, was updating a mural he had painted on a tree trunk in 2021. He took inspiration from Bad Bunny’s Super Bowl halftime show.</p><div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="Enhancement-item" data-crop=""> <figure class="Figure"><a class="AnchorLink" He says he was inspired by Bad Bunny’s Super Bowl halftime performance.</p></figcaption><span class="line"></span><div class="Figure-credit"><p>Anthony Vazquez/Sun-Times</p></div></div> </figure> </div> </div><p>“Too much time inside,” Rodriguez said of the winter.</p><p>Nathan Adams, 7, was climbing a tree stump as his dad Eric looked on. They had biked to the park and planned to go have lunch after.</p><p>“Trying to get him off the screens,” the father said of Nathan. “Just trying to enjoy the park. This park is a great park. And I want him to kind of grow up in this park so he knows the ins and outs. aria-label="Previous"> <svg class="FlickityCustomNavigation-button-icon"><use xlink:href="#icon-left"></use></svg> </button> <button class="FlickityCustomNavigation-button-next" type="button" aria-label="Next"> <svg class="FlickityCustomNavigation-button-icon"><use xlink:href="#icon-right"></use></svg> </button> </div> </div></div> </bsp-carousel> </div> </div><p>After dipping to 47 degrees Tuesday, the high will be 62 Wednesday, the NWS says. If the weather stays on the warmer side, however, there’s a scenario where Monday through Thursday could all hit the 60s. That would be the warmest few February days since 2017, when temps hit the high 60s and 70s for four days.</p><p>Does this warm stretch indicate the cold and snow are behind us?</p><div class="RelatedList Enhancement" data-module data-align-center> <div class="RelatedList-title">Related</div> <ul class="RelatedList-items"> <li class="RelatedList-items-item"> <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/weather/2025/01/21/arctic-blast-hits-chicago-area-with-dangerously-cold-temps-wind-chills-29-degrees-below-zero" >Arctic blast hits Chicago area with dangerously cold temps, wind chills 29 degrees below zero</a> </li> <li class="RelatedList-items-item"> <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/weather/2025/12/07/temperatures-snow-chicago-weather-forecast-cold" >Chicago records 17.1 inches of snow — the most by Dec. 7 since 1978</a> </li> </ul> </div> <p>“No, we just got locked into a warmer pattern here for a little bit,” National Weather Service meteorologist Zachary Yack said. “Things may change back the other way, who knows? But it doesn’t really give us any indication one way or the other.”</p><p>In fact, real Chicagoans shouldn’t be surprised to learn what could be in store for us by Friday, according to the NWS: Even more snow.</p><p><i>Contributing: Mary Norkol</i></p>
entries.author: Nader Issa

entries.title: Thomas Pritzker resigns from Hyatt Hotels' board citing Epstein emails
entries.summary: <p>Prominent Illinois civic figure <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/2017/10/17/18400266/battle-of-billionaires-pritzker-and-pal-of-rauner-make-forbes-cut" target="_blank" ><u>Thomas Pritzker</u></a> stepped down as executive chairman of Chicago-based Hyatt Hotels Corp., the company announced Monday.</p><p>The news comes months after recently released documents show convicted sex offender <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/washington/2025/11/19/jeffrey-epstein-thomas-pritzker-emails-deeper-ties-jb-pritzker-cousin" target="_blank" ><u>Jeffrey Epstein</u></a> exchanged at least 20 emails with Pritzker, who is Gov. JB Pritzker’s cousin, for years after Epstein's 2008 plea deal on sex crimes charges.</p><p>“My job and responsibility is to provide good stewardship,” Thomas Pritzker said in a news release Monday. “Good stewardship also means protecting Hyatt, particularly in the context of my association with Jeffrey Epstein and Ghislaine Maxwell, which I deeply regret. I exercised terrible judgment in maintaining contact with them, and there is no excuse for failing to distance myself sooner. I condemn the actions and the harm caused by Epstein and Maxwell and I feel deep sorrow for the pain they inflicted on their victims.”</p><p>Pritzker, 75, has not been accused of any wrongdoing, nor has he been named in any investigation into Epstein’s crimes.</p><p>In email exchanges, Pritzker and Epstein remarked on current events and made plans to see each other, according to a review of some of the 20,000 pages of <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/politics/2025/07/17/sen-dick-durbin-requests-immediate-release-epstein-files" target="_blank" ><u>documents</u></a>.</p><p>The emails stretch from at least 2010 — two years after Epstein was convicted of soliciting sex from a child as young as 14 — to early 2019, the year Epstein was arrested on suspicion of child sex trafficking. Epstein killed himself <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/2021/8/26/22643714/troubled-jail-where-jeffrey-epstein-killed-himself-closing" target="_blank" ><u>in jail</u></a><u> in Manhattan</u>, according to the local medical examiner.</p><p>Pritzker informed Hyatt’s board of directors that he has retired as executive chairman, effective immediately, according to a news release Monday. He will not seek re-election to its board of directors at Hyatt’s annual stockholders’ meeting in May.</p><p>He also serves as executive chairman of The Pritzker Organization, an investment firm, and as a member of the board of trustees of the University of Chicago. Neither immediately responded to requests for comment late Monday afternoon.</p><p>Pritzker wrote in a letter to Hyatt’s board that he and his wife, Margot, “are now in a phase of our lives where we are thinking about good stewardship and that includes structuring a proper handoff to the future.”</p><p>He added, “For 70 years, Hyatt has been part of our family’s identity and our family has been part of Hyatt’s identity. Good stewardship is very important to me personally.”</p><p>Pritzker served as a Hyatt board member and as executive chairman since August 2004. Mark Hoplamazian, Hyatt’s president and chief executive, succeeds Pritzker as chairman of the board, effective immediately.</p><div class="RelatedList Enhancement" data-module data-align-center> <div class="RelatedList-title">Related</div> <ul class="RelatedList-items"> <li class="RelatedList-items-item"> <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/columnists/2026/02/08/gerhard-richter-most-expensive-painting-ever-sold-2013-park-hyatt-chicago-lobby" >One of the most expensive paintings by a living artist hung unnoticed in a Downtown hotel lobby</a> </li> <li class="RelatedList-items-item"> <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/obituaries/2025/03/16/cindy-pritzker-obituary-matriarch-illinois-hyatt-architecture-library" >Cindy Pritzker, beloved family matriarch and philanthropist, dies at 101</a> </li> </ul> </div> <p>Hoplamazian said in a news release: “Tom’s decision reflects his stewardship and strong commitment to Hyatt over his many decades of service. Looking ahead, we remain focused on executing our strategy for long-term growth, advancing care for our colleagues, delivering meaningful experiences for our guests, and driving performance for owners and value for our stockholders.”</p><p>Hyatt's portfolio contains more than 1,500 hotels and all-inclusive properties in 83 countries across six continents as of the end of 2025, according to the company.<br></p>
entries.author: Amy Yee

entries.title: Horoscope for Tuesday, February 17, 2026
entries.summary: <h2>Moon Alert</h2> <p>Avoid shopping (except food and gas) and major decisions from 5:45 a.m. to 8:30 a.m. Note: The New Moon peaks today at 6:01 a.m. After that, the moon moves from Aquarius into Pisces.</p><h2>Aries (March 21-April 19)</h2> <p></p> <div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="HtmlModule"><a class="AnchorLink" id="html-embed-module-7b0000" name="html-embed-module-7b0000"></a><div class="HoroscopeStarbox HoroscopeStarbox_five"> <div class="HoroscopeStarbox_container"> <svg class="HoroscopeStar"><use xlink:href="#icon-star"></use></svg> <svg class="HoroscopeStar"><use xlink:href="#icon-star"></use></svg> <svg class="HoroscopeStar"><use xlink:href="#icon-star"></use></svg> <svg class="HoroscopeStar"><use xlink:href="#icon-star"></use></svg> </div> <div class="HoroscopeStarbox_description"> <p>A <b>positive</b> day</p> </div> </div> <style> .HoroscopeStarbox { background: #f8f8f8; display: flex; align-items: center; } .HoroscopeStarbox_container { display: grid; grid-gap: 5px; grid-template-columns: 1fr 1fr 1fr 1fr 1fr; padding: 20px; width: 40%; min-width: 160px; max-width: 200px; } .HoroscopeStarbox_description { padding: 20px; font-family: var(--font-1); font-size: var(--body-2); } .HoroscopeStarbox_container svg { object-fit: cover; aspect-ratio: 1 / 1; width: 100%; } </style> </div> </div><p> We are gregarious creatures. We need to see others, and we also need to be seen. Think about how you can improve your closest friendships today. What kind of friend are you to others? The key to having friends is to be friendly.</p><h2>Taurus (April 20-May 20)</h2> <p></p> <div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="HtmlModule"><a class="AnchorLink" id="html-embed-module-4d0000" name="html-embed-module-4d0000"></a><div class="HoroscopeStarbox HoroscopeStarbox_five"> <div class="HoroscopeStarbox_container"> <svg class="HoroscopeStar"><use xlink:href="#icon-star"></use></svg> <svg class="HoroscopeStar"><use xlink:href="#icon-star"></use></svg> <svg class="HoroscopeStar"><use xlink:href="#icon-star"></use></svg> </div> <div class="HoroscopeStarbox_description"> <p>An <b>average</b> day</p> </div> </div> <style> .HoroscopeStarbox { background: #f8f8f8; display: flex; align-items: center; } .HoroscopeStarbox_container { display: grid; grid-gap: 5px; grid-template-columns: 1fr 1fr 1fr 1fr 1fr; padding: 20px; width: 40%; min-width: 160px; max-width: 200px; } .HoroscopeStarbox_description { padding: 20px; font-family: var(--font-1); font-size: var(--body-2); } .HoroscopeStarbox_container svg { object-fit: cover; aspect-ratio: 1 / 1; width: 100%; } </style> </div> </div><p> Today's new moon occurs at the top of your chart, offering you a chance to think about your life direction. Where do you want to be one year from now? This is the day to look at your attitude toward authority figures — the police, your boss, parents, and the government.</p><h2>Gemini (May 21-June 20)</h2> <p></p> <div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="HtmlModule"><a class="AnchorLink" id="html-embed-module-7b0000" name="html-embed-module-7b0000"></a><div class="HoroscopeStarbox HoroscopeStarbox_five"> <div class="HoroscopeStarbox_container"> <svg class="HoroscopeStar"><use xlink:href="#icon-star"></use></svg> <svg class="HoroscopeStar"><use xlink:href="#icon-star"></use></svg> <svg class="HoroscopeStar"><use xlink:href="#icon-star"></use></svg> <svg class="HoroscopeStar"><use xlink:href="#icon-star"></use></svg> </div> <div class="HoroscopeStarbox_description"> <p>A <b>positive</b> day</p> </div> </div> <style> .HoroscopeStarbox { background: #f8f8f8; display: flex; align-items: center; } .HoroscopeStarbox_container { display: grid; grid-gap: 5px; grid-template-columns: 1fr 1fr 1fr 1fr 1fr; padding: 20px; width: 40%; min-width: 160px; max-width: 200px; } .HoroscopeStarbox_description { padding: 20px; font-family: var(--font-1); font-size: var(--body-2); } .HoroscopeStarbox_container svg { object-fit: cover; aspect-ratio: 1 / 1; width: 100%; } </style> </div> </div><p> This is the perfect day to take stock of your education and your life experiences. What further education or training might improve your job? What about travel? Do you want to broaden your experience of the world by seeing new places and meeting new people?</p><h2>Cancer (June 21-July 22)</h2> <p></p> <div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="HtmlModule"><a class="AnchorLink" id="html-embed-module-4d0000" name="html-embed-module-4d0000"></a><div class="HoroscopeStarbox HoroscopeStarbox_five"> <div class="HoroscopeStarbox_container"> <svg class="HoroscopeStar"><use xlink:href="#icon-star"></use></svg> <svg class="HoroscopeStar"><use xlink:href="#icon-star"></use></svg> <svg class="HoroscopeStar"><use xlink:href="#icon-star"></use></svg> </div> <div class="HoroscopeStarbox_description"> <p>An <b>average</b> day</p> </div> </div> <style> .HoroscopeStarbox { background: #f8f8f8; display: flex; align-items: center; } .HoroscopeStarbox_container { display: grid; grid-gap: 5px; grid-template-columns: 1fr 1fr 1fr 1fr 1fr; padding: 20px; width: 40%; min-width: 160px; max-width: 200px; } .HoroscopeStarbox_description { padding: 20px; font-family: var(--font-1); font-size: var(--body-2); } .HoroscopeStarbox_container svg { object-fit: cover; aspect-ratio: 1 / 1; width: 100%; } </style> </div> </div><p> The new moon today is the best day all year to think about your shared assets with the government, credit card companies, etc. In other words, what is your debt scene? How independent are you, and how much do you rely on others? (Of course, we all rely on others.)</p><h2>Leo (July 23-Aug. 22)</h2> <p></p> <div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="HtmlModule"><a class="AnchorLink" id="html-embed-module-4d0000" name="html-embed-module-4d0000"></a><div class="HoroscopeStarbox HoroscopeStarbox_five"> <div class="HoroscopeStarbox_container"> <svg class="HoroscopeStar"><use xlink:href="#icon-star"></use></svg> <svg class="HoroscopeStar"><use xlink:href="#icon-star"></use></svg> <svg class="HoroscopeStar"><use xlink:href="#icon-star"></use></svg> </div> <div class="HoroscopeStarbox_description"> <p>An <b>average</b> day</p> </div> </div> <style> .HoroscopeStarbox { background: #f8f8f8; display: flex; align-items: center; } .HoroscopeStarbox_container { display: grid; grid-gap: 5px; grid-template-columns: 1fr 1fr 1fr 1fr 1fr; padding: 20px; width: 40%; min-width: 160px; max-width: 200px; } .HoroscopeStarbox_description { padding: 20px; font-family: var(--font-1); font-size: var(--body-2); } .HoroscopeStarbox_container svg { object-fit: cover; aspect-ratio: 1 / 1; width: 100%; } </style> </div> </div><p> Today, the new moon is opposite your sign, prompting you to think about your long-term committed relationships. We often attract people who meet our self-fulfilling prophecies. What do you expect from others? What do others expect from you?</p><h2>Virgo (Aug. 23-Sept. 22)</h2> <p></p> <div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="HtmlModule"><a class="AnchorLink" id="html-embed-module-4d0000" name="html-embed-module-4d0000"></a><div class="HoroscopeStarbox HoroscopeStarbox_five"> <div class="HoroscopeStarbox_container"> <svg class="HoroscopeStar"><use xlink:href="#icon-star"></use></svg> <svg class="HoroscopeStar"><use xlink:href="#icon-star"></use></svg> <svg class="HoroscopeStar"><use xlink:href="#icon-star"></use></svg> </div> <div class="HoroscopeStarbox_description"> <p>An <b>average</b> day</p> </div> </div> <style> .HoroscopeStarbox { background: #f8f8f8; display: flex; align-items: center; } .HoroscopeStarbox_container { display: grid; grid-gap: 5px; grid-template-columns: 1fr 1fr 1fr 1fr 1fr; padding: 20px; width: 40%; min-width: 160px; max-width: 200px; } .HoroscopeStarbox_description { padding: 20px; font-family: var(--font-1); font-size: var(--body-2); } .HoroscopeStarbox_container svg { object-fit: cover; aspect-ratio: 1 / 1; width: 100%; } </style> </div> </div><p> Once a year, the new moon urges you to ponder how you can improve your job or how you do your work. It's also the best day to think about what you can do to improve your health. Don't take your body for granted. Cherish it.</p><h2>Libra (Sept. 23-Oct. 22)</h2> <p></p> <div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="HtmlModule"><a class="AnchorLink" id="html-embed-module-7b0000" name="html-embed-module-7b0000"></a><div class="HoroscopeStarbox HoroscopeStarbox_five"> <div class="HoroscopeStarbox_container"> <svg class="HoroscopeStar"><use xlink:href="#icon-star"></use></svg> <svg class="HoroscopeStar"><use xlink:href="#icon-star"></use></svg> <svg class="HoroscopeStar"><use xlink:href="#icon-star"></use></svg> <svg class="HoroscopeStar"><use xlink:href="#icon-star"></use></svg> </div> <div class="HoroscopeStarbox_description"> <p>A <b>positive</b> day</p> </div> </div> <style> .HoroscopeStarbox { background: #f8f8f8; display: flex; align-items: center; } .HoroscopeStarbox_container { display: grid; grid-gap: 5px; grid-template-columns: 1fr 1fr 1fr 1fr 1fr; padding: 20px; width: 40%; min-width: 160px; max-width: 200px; } .HoroscopeStarbox_description { padding: 20px; font-family: var(--font-1); font-size: var(--body-2); } .HoroscopeStarbox_container svg { object-fit: cover; aspect-ratio: 1 / 1; width: 100%; } </style> </div> </div><p> You appreciate beauty. You're aware of lighting, colors, fragrances, the composition of furniture and spatial relations. Think about how the arts, as well as romance and children, enrich your life.</p><h2>Scorpio (Oct. 23-Nov. 21)</h2> <p></p> <div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="HtmlModule"><a class="AnchorLink" id="html-embed-module-4d0000" name="html-embed-module-4d0000"></a><div class="HoroscopeStarbox HoroscopeStarbox_five"> <div class="HoroscopeStarbox_container"> <svg class="HoroscopeStar"><use xlink:href="#icon-star"></use></svg> <svg class="HoroscopeStar"><use xlink:href="#icon-star"></use></svg> <svg class="HoroscopeStar"><use xlink:href="#icon-star"></use></svg> </div> <div class="HoroscopeStarbox_description"> <p>An <b>average</b> day</p> </div> </div> <style> .HoroscopeStarbox { background: #f8f8f8; display: flex; align-items: center; } .HoroscopeStarbox_container { display: grid; grid-gap: 5px; grid-template-columns: 1fr 1fr 1fr 1fr 1fr; padding: 20px; width: 40%; min-width: 160px; max-width: 200px; } .HoroscopeStarbox_description { padding: 20px; font-family: var(--font-1); font-size: var(--body-2); } .HoroscopeStarbox_container svg { object-fit: cover; aspect-ratio: 1 / 1; width: 100%; } </style> </div> </div><p> This is an excellent day to think about your security, your home and your relations with family. These are important issues, and today's new moon is the best day of the year to think about how you can make these relationships mutually supportive.</p><h2>Sagittarius (Nov. 22-Dec. 21)</h2> <p></p> <div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="HtmlModule"><a class="AnchorLink" id="html-embed-module-7b0000" name="html-embed-module-7b0000"></a><div class="HoroscopeStarbox HoroscopeStarbox_five"> <div class="HoroscopeStarbox_container"> <svg class="HoroscopeStar"><use xlink:href="#icon-star"></use></svg> <svg class="HoroscopeStar"><use xlink:href="#icon-star"></use></svg> <svg class="HoroscopeStar"><use xlink:href="#icon-star"></use></svg> <svg class="HoroscopeStar"><use xlink:href="#icon-star"></use></svg> </div> <div class="HoroscopeStarbox_description"> <p>A <b>positive</b> day</p> </div> </div> <style> .HoroscopeStarbox { background: #f8f8f8; display: flex; align-items: center; } .HoroscopeStarbox_container { display: grid; grid-gap: 5px; grid-template-columns: 1fr 1fr 1fr 1fr 1fr; padding: 20px; width: 40%; min-width: 160px; max-width: 200px; } .HoroscopeStarbox_description { padding: 20px; font-family: var(--font-1); font-size: var(--body-2); } .HoroscopeStarbox_container svg { object-fit: cover; aspect-ratio: 1 / 1; width: 100%; } </style> </div> </div><p> Today's new moon is an excellent day to think about your style of communicating with others. Do you wait for others to speak first? Are you friendly or suspicious? Talking, reading and listening are food for your soul.</p><h2>Capricorn (Dec. 22-Jan. 19)</h2> <p></p> <div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="HtmlModule"><a class="AnchorLink" id="html-embed-module-4d0000" name="html-embed-module-4d0000"></a><div class="HoroscopeStarbox HoroscopeStarbox_five"> <div class="HoroscopeStarbox_container"> <svg class="HoroscopeStar"><use xlink:href="#icon-star"></use></svg> <svg class="HoroscopeStar"><use xlink:href="#icon-star"></use></svg> <svg class="HoroscopeStar"><use xlink:href="#icon-star"></use></svg> </div> <div class="HoroscopeStarbox_description"> <p>An <b>average</b> day</p> </div> </div> <style> .HoroscopeStarbox { background: #f8f8f8; display: flex; align-items: center; } .HoroscopeStarbox_container { display: grid; grid-gap: 5px; grid-template-columns: 1fr 1fr 1fr 1fr 1fr; padding: 20px; width: 40%; min-width: 160px; max-width: 200px; } .HoroscopeStarbox_description { padding: 20px; font-family: var(--font-1); font-size: var(--body-2); } .HoroscopeStarbox_container svg { object-fit: cover; aspect-ratio: 1 / 1; width: 100%; } </style> </div> </div><p> The new moon today occurs in your money house, which means it's your chance to think about your attitude toward money. Which type are you? Do you think "Easy come, easy go"? Or, like most Capricorns, do you agree that "A penny saved is a penny earned"?</p><h2>Aquarius (Jan. 20-Feb. 18)</h2> <p></p> <div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="HtmlModule"><a class="AnchorLink" id="html-embed-module-7b0000" name="html-embed-module-7b0000"></a><div class="HoroscopeStarbox HoroscopeStarbox_five"> <div class="HoroscopeStarbox_container"> <svg class="HoroscopeStar"><use xlink:href="#icon-star"></use></svg> <svg class="HoroscopeStar"><use xlink:href="#icon-star"></use></svg> <svg class="HoroscopeStar"><use xlink:href="#icon-star"></use></svg> <svg class="HoroscopeStar"><use xlink:href="#icon-star"></use></svg> </div> <div class="HoroscopeStarbox_description"> <p>A <b>positive</b> day</p> </div> </div> <style> .HoroscopeStarbox { background: #f8f8f8; display: flex; align-items: center; } .HoroscopeStarbox_container { display: grid; grid-gap: 5px; grid-template-columns: 1fr 1fr 1fr 1fr 1fr; padding: 20px; width: 40%; min-width: 160px; max-width: 200px; } .HoroscopeStarbox_description { padding: 20px; font-family: var(--font-1); font-size: var(--body-2); } .HoroscopeStarbox_container svg { object-fit: cover; aspect-ratio: 1 / 1; width: 100%; } </style> </div> </div><p> Today, the only new moon in your sign all year is taking place, giving you a chance to think about how others see you. After all, you never get a second chance to make a first impression. Are you pleased with the image you project?</p><h2>Pisces (Feb. 19-March 20)</h2> <p></p> <div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="HtmlModule"><a class="AnchorLink" id="html-embed-module-4d0000" name="html-embed-module-4d0000"></a><div class="HoroscopeStarbox HoroscopeStarbox_five"> <div class="HoroscopeStarbox_container"> <svg class="HoroscopeStar"><use xlink:href="#icon-star"></use></svg> <svg class="HoroscopeStar"><use xlink:href="#icon-star"></use></svg> <svg class="HoroscopeStar"><use xlink:href="#icon-star"></use></svg> </div> <div class="HoroscopeStarbox_description"> <p>An <b>average</b> day</p> </div> </div> <style> .HoroscopeStarbox { background: #f8f8f8; display: flex; align-items: center; } .HoroscopeStarbox_container { display: grid; grid-gap: 5px; grid-template-columns: 1fr 1fr 1fr 1fr 1fr; padding: 20px; width: 40%; min-width: 160px; max-width: 200px; } .HoroscopeStarbox_description { padding: 20px; font-family: var(--font-1); font-size: var(--body-2); } .HoroscopeStarbox_container svg { object-fit: cover; aspect-ratio: 1 / 1; width: 100%; } </style> </div> </div><p> The new moon today is taking place in a hidden part of your chart dealing with secret emotions and subconscious patterns of behavior. It's a chance for you to think about how you might act in self-defeating ways that sabotage your best interests. (Be aware of this.)</p><h2>If today is your birthday</h2><p>Actor Joseph Gordon-Levitt (1981) shares your birthday today. You're sensitive, observant and trusting. You're also determined and passionate about individual freedom. This is a slower-paced year. Take time to rest and rejuvenate yourself. Spend time with people who are kind, helpful and supportive. Find relationships that benefit you now and in the future. </p>
entries.author: Georgia Nicols

entries.title: Obama shuts down alien buzz and says there's no evidence they've made contact with earthlings
entries.summary: <p>Former U.S. President Barack Obama said he did not see evidence that aliens “have made contact with us,” after sending social media abuzz by saying aliens were real on a podcast over the weekend.</p><p>During a lightning round of questions with podcast host Brian Tyler Cohen, Obama was asked, “Are aliens real?”</p><p>“They’re real,” he answered, continuing: “But I haven’t seen them. And, they’re not being kept in Area 51.”</p><p>On Sunday, the former president released a statement on Instagram, appearing to clarify what he meant by his comments that have since gone viral.</p><div </div></div><p>“I was trying to stick with the spirit of the speed round, but since it’s gotten attention let me clarify. Statistically, the universe is so vast that the odds are good there’s life out there. But the distances between solar systems are so great that the chances we’ve been visited by aliens is low, and I saw no evidence during my presidency that extraterrestrials have made contact with us. Really!”</p><p>Secrecy around Area 51, a top-secret Cold War test site in the Nevada desert, has long fueled conspiracy theories among UFO enthusiasts.</p><p>In 2013, the CIA acknowledged the existence of the site, but not UFO crashes, black-eyed extraterrestrials or staged moon landings.</p><p>Declassified documents referred to the 8,000-square-mile installation by name after decades of U.S. government officials refusing to acknowledge it.</p><div class="RelatedList Enhancement" data-module data-align-center> <div class="RelatedList-title">Related</div> <ul class="RelatedList-items"> <li class="RelatedList-items-item"> <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/architecture-design/2025/12/08/obama-presidential-center-home-court-building-opened-exclusive-look" >Obama Presidential Center’s first building is complete — Here’s an exclusive look</a> </li> <li class="RelatedList-items-item"> <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/columnists/2019/10/29/20939079/obama-presidential-center-mothership-post-presidency-jackson-park" >The Obama Presidential Center: Obama’s ‘mothership’ for his post-presidency</a> </li> </ul> </div> <p>The base has been a testing ground for a host of top-secret aircraft, including the U2 in the 1950s and later the B-2 stealth bomber.<br></p>
entries.author: AP

entries.title: Bitcoin has value to many people around the world
entries.summary: <p>Bitcoin is back in the headlines again. As always, the story is volatility. Prices fall. Prices rise. Critics cheer. Believers celebrate. The cycle repeats.</p><p>But the headlines miss the deeper story.</p><p>I learned to respect Bitcoin not from traders or tech executives. I learned from dissidents and from people who lived through economic collapse. For them, Bitcoin was not about getting rich. It was about staying free.</p><p>Across the world, people facing repression or broken economies have learned the same lesson. When institutions fail, the ability to hold value outside the reach of rulers can mean the difference between fear and agency.</p><p>For many, this is daily life. Governments freeze bank accounts to punish journalists. Activists lose access to wages. Savings disappear under inflation. In those places, economic freedom and personal freedom are the same thing.</p><div class="RichTextSidebarModule Enhancement" data-module data-align-center><a class="AnchorLink" id="module-990000" name="module-990000"></a> <div class="RichTextSidebarModule-title">Columnist </div> <div class="RichTextModule-items RichTextBody">Columnist</div> </div><p>Look at Venezuela. At the height of its collapse, inflation soared toward 1 million percent. Teachers were paid in bills worth less than bus fare. Millions fled. Those who stayed survived with dollars, remittances and, increasingly, Bitcoin. The state could not inflate it away or block it with a phone call.</p><p>In neighboring Colombia, artists began weaving worthless Venezuelan banknotes into bags and purses. Money that once held savings became craft material. It was worth more as fabric than as currency. That image stays with me.</p><p>Look at Nigeria. A government cash redesign left families without money. Activists saw accounts restricted. Many turned to Bitcoin simply to keep life moving — paying school fees, receiving money from relatives abroad, keeping businesses alive. Not out of fashion. Out of necessity.</p><p>A former graduate student of mine, Jacqueline Escobar, of Peru, wrote to me about why she believes in Bitcoin. She grew up during hyperinflation. As a child, she played with paper money that had suddenly become worthless. “I played with money that no longer had value,” she told me. “That’s when you learn that systems can fail.” Her father lost his business. Her family lost their home.</p><p>The experience shaped her path. She became a fintech lawyer, drawn to how financial systems can expand — or deny — human freedom. For her, Bitcoin became a lifeline. It offered a road back toward middle-class stability and a steadier alternative to a system people no longer trusted.</p><p>This past fall, at the Black Blockchain Summit at Howard University, activists from the African continent reminded me that refugees face the same reality. In conversations there, people told me that crossing a border often means losing access to banks, documents and savings overnight — and that Bitcoin can travel when everything else is confiscated or left behind.</p><p>Years ago, dissidents living inside a wealthy Asian nation known for severe repression told me how the state could erase people economically before ever touching them physically. Control the money and you control the person.</p><p>Bitcoin matters because it is different from the carnival of other digital coins. It has no company. No CEO. No marketing department. Its supply is fixed. Its rules are public. It is recognized around the world the way gold is recognized — by habit and trust, not by decree.</p><p>I do not confuse Bitcoin with the broader digital-coin marketplace. Stablecoins tied to the dollar have practical uses for remittances and payments. But many alternative coins look like casinos dressed as technology. Bitcoin stands apart because it answers one narrow question well: how can ordinary people store value beyond the reach of rulers?</p><p>There are real concerns. Bitcoin uses significant energy, and that energy increasingly needs to come from renewables if the technology is to align with climate goals. Those debates matter. None erase the core fact that the network itself belongs to no government and no bank.</p><p>Critics say Bitcoin is volatile. They are right. So are currencies run by politicians. Critics say criminals use it. Criminals also use dollars and shell companies and a banking system that launders far more dirty money every year than Bitcoin ever has. The question is not whether a tool can be abused. The question is who controls it.</p><p>I pray we never need such tools here. I want my children to trust courts more than code. But history humbles proud nations. Emergency powers sold as temporary have a habit of staying.</p><p>Whenever I listen to people who escaped repression, they speak of Bitcoin the way earlier generations spoke of safe houses — as the difference between begging and choosing.</p><p>Markets will rise and fall. Human beings will still need freedom.</p><p>That is why I believe the world will always need Bitcoin.</p><p><i>Ben Jealous is a professor of practice at the University of Pennsylvania and former president and CEO of the NAACP.</i></p><div class="RichTextSidebarModule Enhancement" data-module data-align-center><a class="AnchorLink" id="module-360000" name="module-360000"></a> <div class="RichTextSidebarModule-title">Commentary bug</div> <div class="RichTextModule-items RichTextBody"><h2>Commentary</h2></div> </div><p></p>
entries.author: Ben Jealous

entries.title: Dear Abby: Spouse's world turned upside down with pair of revelations
entries.summary: <p><b>DEAR ABBY:</b> My husband and I (both male) have been together for 28 years. The last few years have been less than romantic, but we remain close and in love (or so I thought).</p><p>A few days ago, he called me from work (I'm retired) crying so hard I could hardly understand him. I rushed to his office, and he told me he had just learned from his doctor that he has AIDS. He then confessed that he'd had an affair with a contractor at his place of employment. He said it happened years ago when we were going through a rough patch, and swore it was the only time he had strayed.</p><p>I am awaiting the results of my HIV test, heartbroken and crushed. What now? I'm so hurt; I don't know if I should stay or go. — <i>CRUSHED IN FLORIDA</i></p><p><b>DEAR CRUSHED:</b> Your first order of business should be to ensure you and your husband are getting the best medical advice and treatment possible. A diagnosis of HIV-positive does not necessarily mean the disease will progress to full-blown AIDS because with the advances in medication, it can be held in check. Whether you should stay with your husband or leave is a question that should be tabled until you are less traumatized and thinking rationally.</p><p><b>DEAR ABBY:</b> Two of my children are planning weddings two months apart next year. I'm originally from the Netherlands, where my entire family still lives. My kids both want to invite these relatives (which is great), except my parents are 86 and 87 and can make it to only one wedding. For my sisters, nieces and nephews, it's too costly to come to both. They don't want to hurt anyone's feelings, and I have no idea how to advise them about which wedding to attend.</p><p>My son said he will help them financially if they need it so they can come to both, but even so, I know it would not be possible for my parents to come to both. Any advice? — <i>CHALLENGED IN IDAHO</i></p><p><b>DEAR CHALLENGED:</b> I do have one suggestion: STEP BACK! It should not be your responsibility to orchestrate who will attend which wedding. Invitations should be sent to everyone. After that, I'm sure conversations will ensue. If financial help is needed, your son is offering it.</p><p>Should your parents' degree of infirmity prevent them from attending both celebrations, the decision about which they will attend should be theirs. Even if they can't be there in person for both, these days many weddings are livestreamed, and photos and videos can be shared on social media.</p><p>TO MY ASIAN READERS WHO CELEBRATE THE LUNAR NEW YEAR: The Lunar New Year begins today. This is the Year of the Horse. According to Asian culture, individuals born in the year of the horse are dynamic, charming and adventurous. They thrive in settings that are bustling with activity and are often seen as natural leaders and motivators. A healthy, happy and prosperous New Year to you all. Tallyho! — <i>LOVE, ABBY</i></p><p><i>Dear Abby is written by Abigail Van Buren, also known as Jeanne Phillips, and was founded by her mother, Pauline Phillips. Contact Dear Abby at www.DearAbby.com or P.O. Box 69440, Los Angeles, CA 90069.</i></p><p>What teens need to know about sex, drugs, AIDS and getting along with peers and parents is in "What Every Teen Should Know." Send your name and mailing address, plus check or money order for $8 (U.S. funds) to: Dear Abby, Teen Booklet, P.O. Box 446, Kings Mills, OH 45034-0446. (Shipping and handling are included in the price.)</p>
entries.author: Abigail Van Buren

entries.title: Formerly incarcerated celebrate passage of Illinois' Clean Slate Act
entries.summary: <p>SPRINGFIELD — After completing nearly a decade behind bars, Chauncy Stockdale was hopeful the worst was behind him. But he quickly met with the challenges many formerly incarcerated people face after being released.</p><p>Stockdale spent weeks looking for employment. He had multiple interviews and received a handful of job offers but could never get past the background check.</p><p>“I couldn't even get a job helping my mom out,” Stockdale said after applying to be a caregiver for his mom, who had just come out of surgery. “I already had home patient experience, and I still couldn't get the job because of the things in my background.”</p><p>Stockdale is now one of the beneficiaries of a new law enacted by Gov. JB Pritzker called the Clean Slate Act, which helps streamline the reentry process for people with criminal records.</p><p>Starting in 2029, people who have committed certain non-violent felonies will automatically have their records sealed two to three years after the completion of their punishment, as long as no more offenses are committed. It’s a change that could impact close to 2 million Illinoisans.</p><p>The sealing process was already available, but it required people to obtain sealing approval through months-long court procedures that cost money.</p><p>Stockdale’s first criminal offense came from a trespassing case when he was just 17. After two six-month jail sentences for theft in Ohio and Texas in 2008 and 2009, he returned home to Chicago. At that time, Stockdale said things “were looking good.” He had gotten married, started a family and found work.</p><p>But in early 2012, Stockdale was struggling with the loss of his job as well as a separation from his partner. In February of that year, he was convicted of aggravated robbery and residential burglary, leading Stockdale to be sentenced to nine years in prison.</p><p>Stockdale said the event made him realize he needed to make a change. The next few years in prison, he set goals for himself, got in touch with religion and prepared himself for reentry.</p><p>“While we're in prison, that's time we'll never get back, so we might as well use that time to the best of our ability,” Stockdale said. “Now I’ve got a different mindset, instead of trying to go out there and just take, take, take, because I'm hurting, let me go create something.”</p><p>Stockdale now works as a program coordinator for the Illinois Alliance for Reentry and Justice, a nonprofit organization that works to support individuals who have served prison sentences as they return to society. Among his other duties, he helps formerly incarcerated people get their GED and health insurance, learn how to budget and establish goals for reentry that help keep them from being reincarcerated.</p><p>Stockdale said the new state law will enhance his ability to help ex-offenders reintegrate into society.</p><p>“I can talk to people when I do community events with some of the organizations, and it's a little easier to talk to them because it’s like, ‘Hey, we got hope now,'” Stockdale said.</p><p>The new law passed the legislature with bipartisan support and will not include crimes like murder, sex-offenses, human trafficking, drunk-driving or domestic violence. Of the 2.2 million adults in Illinois with a criminal record, an estimated 1.74 million would have their records fully or partially sealed from the Clean Slate Act. Critics argue the implementation of the bill will cost the state $20 million over the next five years.</p><p>“This legislation is about empowering eligible people who seek a second chance to make their own choices about their futures and to get themselves on the right path,” Pritzker said when he signed the legislation.</p><p>Antonio Lightfoot, deputy director of the Illinois Coalition to End Permanent Punishments , helped lobby for the passage of the Clean Slate Act.</p><p>Lightfoot was incarcerated from 2006 to 2009 and, like Stockdale, faced challenges finding employment and housing after his sentence before landing in his current job. In 2020, he helped host a sealing expungement workshop where attorneys were invited to talk about the sealing process. Even though he helped set up the event, the attorney’s presentations were the first time Lightfoot learned his record was sealable.</p><p>“Even people who work in this space don’t know,” Lightfoot said. “A lot of folks don’t even know their record is eligible for sealing. ”</p><p>Lightfoot was better-equipped for the court’s sealing process than most. He had connections to public figures who wrote letters of recommendation and testified in court on his behalf as well as the money to pay for court fees. Even with that, the process of getting his record sealed took Lightfoot about nine months.</p><p>“Not everybody has the time to take out their day, to go down and spend all day in a courtroom filing petitions,” Lightfoot said. “Most folks who are struggling can't afford to take a day off work.”</p><p>The Clean Slate Initiative is a national movement that has passed similar laws in 12 other states and in Washington, D.C.</p><p>Artinese Myrick, deputy director of Live Free Illinois, a faith-based community group focused on addressing social issues, explained the law has been years in the making.</p><p>When Myrick was 9, her mother, father and stepfather were all incarcerated at the same time.</p><p>“They were being denied jobs because of their background and the stigma itself,” Myrick said. “Because of that, I'm interested in making sure that systems can be of support for families like mine.”</p><p>Having been unable to seal their records through court procedures, she says her family members are all excited for the passage of the Clean Slate Act.</p>
entries.author: Matt Trunfio

entries.title: Irving Park studio gets visitors to 'slow down' by spinning wool into yarn
entries.summary: <p>Since opening in November, a 600-square-foot space in Irving Park has been home to people looking to slow down thanks to wooden tools used to spin raw wool into yarn. </p><p>Inclement Craft, 3436 W. Irving Park Road, is a fine fiber retailer and studio space that has created its own community for people, from experienced spinners and fiber artists to those curious about working with yarn. The studio frequently hosts classes such as Handspinning 101 and events like indigo dye parties.</p><p>The fiber arts have gained more popularity, particularly after the pandemic, as the trend of an <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/small-business/2026/01/15/shoppers-chicago-stationery-shops-atlas-paper-pencil-hobonichi-social-media-analog" >analog life</a> — less phones and more human experiences — gains traction this year. </p><p>For those looking to unplug, spinning and the fiber arts are a welcoming hobby, Inclement Craft owners Aaron Storm and Nathaniel Millard said.</p><p>“There’s not a numerical element. You’re not counting," Storm said. "It gets to be a little more mindful."</p><p>Most yarn studios and shops in the Chicago area are focused on knitting and crocheting. But at Inclement Craft, the emphasis is on spinning and hand-dyeing high-quality wool and mulberry silk.</p><p>Spinning is the process of turning loose fiber — like raw wool — into yarn by drafting it out and twisting with a wheel or hand-held spindle. Unlike knitting or crocheting, which uses finished yarn, spinning starts closer to the source. “[It's] the difference between getting your tomato at the grocery store or going to a farmer’s market,” Storm said.</p><div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="Enhancement-item" data-crop=""> <figure class="Figure"><a class="AnchorLink" id="image-d30000" name="image-d30000"></a> <picture 2x" width="490" height="275" data-src="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/2d6f2dd/2147483647/strip/true/crop/7008x3933+0+0/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F9b%2F81%2F05ec9b8d43ea8aeeea7ca468d09a%2Ffibercraft-260213-25.jpg" data-lazy-load="true" src="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" > </picture> <div class="Figure-content"><figcaption class="Figure-caption"><p>Inclement Craft cofounders Nathaniel Millard (left) and Aaron Storm at their store and studio space, where process fiber and teach fiber arts classes.</p></figcaption><span class="line"></span><div class="Figure-credit"><p>Pat Nabong/Sun-Times</p></div></div> </figure> </div> </div><p>While not as popular as knitting, spinning doesn’t require much talent or skill.</p><p>“It [doesn’t] take a huge amount of time to learn,” Storm said. “I think it’s kind of a radical thing to intentionally move so slowly … to be producing cloth and yarn and clothing at the scale of the hand.”</p><p>The founders originally sold finished products on Instagram, where it has more than 14,000 followers, but the operation expanded into a brick-and-mortar store at the end of last year. Millard said the platform is “inextricably linked” to their success.</p><p>“I knew going into this that social media was going to be kind of a necessary evil,” Millard said. “But it's truly been like everything social media was promised to be like.”</p><p>“There's a ton of irony and tension there because I am out here advocating for and teaching these sort of hyper-analog processes; these pre-industrial processes. And in order to drive interest, I'm on social media more than ever,” Storm said. “The boom [of] knitting and crocheting is feeding into a second wave of spinning because people are getting their hands on these materials, learning more about them and then wanting to go a little deeper and take a little bit more control over their own process.”</p><p>Storm, 30, and Millard, 29, started the business after working years in corporate jobs. Storm grew up in rural Indiana, where he got to see wool plucked from sheep then spun into yarn.</p><div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="Enhancement-item" data-crop=""> <figure class="Figure"><a class="AnchorLink" id="image-fc0000" name="image-fc0000"></a> <picture data-crop="medium"> <source type="image/webp" width="490" height="275" data-srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/49e0abd/2147483647/strip/true/crop/6395x3589+0+62/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F05%2F15%2F91cb02064150b90769331a53894a%2Ffibercraft-260213-9.jpg" data-lazy-load="true" srcset="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" /> <img class="Image" alt="Combed tops, made of a blend of wool and silk, are on sale at Inclement Craft, along with other fiber art supplies and accessories." srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/49e0abd/2147483647/strip/true/crop/6395x3589+0+62/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F05%2F15%2F91cb02064150b90769331a53894a%2Ffibercraft-260213-9.jpg 1x,https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/2619b4e/2147483647/strip/true/crop/6395x3589+0+62/resize/980x550!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F05%2F15%2F91cb02064150b90769331a53894a%2Ffibercraft-260213-9.jpg 2x" width="490" height="275" data-src="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/49e0abd/2147483647/strip/true/crop/6395x3589+0+62/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F05%2F15%2F91cb02064150b90769331a53894a%2Ffibercraft-260213-9.jpg" data-lazy-load="true" src="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" > </picture> <div class="Figure-content"><figcaption class="Figure-caption"><p>Combed tops, made of a blend of wool and silk, are on sale at Inclement Craft, along with other fiber art supplies and accessories.</p></figcaption><span class="line"></span><div class="Figure-credit"><p>Pat Nabong/Sun-Times</p></div></div> </figure> </div> </div><p>“I remember wanting a place like this,” Storm said of Inclement Craft. “[Life is] rough out there. Knitting took off in the U.S. after 9/11, and that's when it became the cultural thing it is now. There's the urge to hold something soft; there's the urge to move more slowly; and there's the urge to do something that involves other people.”</p><p>The return to analog trend has played a part in the early success of the studio, they said. And a focus on mental health and self-care activities has also helped.</p><p>“It's very of-the-moment,” Storm said. “I think people tend to be tuned into that, where they come in and expressly are like, ‘I saw you on Instagram, and I'm so excited to be in here and put my phone down.’ I had a student last night for an indigo resist dyeing class … and we were joking, ‘This is the most mentally healthy thing we'll do all week.’”</p><p>Spinning also brings people to a more “farm-to-yarn” way of consuming, Storm said.</p><p>“Yarn is an agricultural product,” he said. </p><h3>Sold out</h3><p>To open the store, the duo spent around $7,000 — most of their materials were already on hand. So far, they’ve opened the store debt-free. Revenue from their classes have been able to cover rent.</p><p>Visitors can buy yarn, products that were made in-house and batts, or the carded fiber used for spinning. Batts are priced on a sliding scale, starting at $20.</p><p>“We want people to be able to access that really high-value, really high-quality product,” Storm said. “We want people to be able to get their hands on it and learn how much they love it without that barrier to access.”</p><p>Revenue is split with 65% from retail sales and 35% from classes, Storm said.</p><div class="Enhancement" width="490" height="275" data-srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/91c432c/2147483647/strip/true/crop/7008x3933+0+390/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Fc5%2F22%2F5b8d557542b48c839db504861f0a%2Ffibercraft-260213-4.jpg" data-lazy-load="true" srcset="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" /> <img class="Image" alt="Fiber is dyed at Inclement Craft in Irving Park." srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/91c432c/2147483647/strip/true/crop/7008x3933+0+390/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Fc5%2F22%2F5b8d557542b48c839db504861f0a%2Ffibercraft-260213-4.jpg 1x,https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/dcb6778/2147483647/strip/true/crop/7008x3933+0+390/resize/980x550!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Fc5%2F22%2F5b8d557542b48c839db504861f0a%2Ffibercraft-260213-4.jpg 2x" width="490" height="275" data-src="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/91c432c/2147483647/strip/true/crop/7008x3933+0+390/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Fc5%2F22%2F5b8d557542b48c839db504861f0a%2Ffibercraft-260213-4.jpg" data-lazy-load="true" src="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" > </picture> <div class="Figure-content"><figcaption class="Figure-caption"><p>Fiber is dyed at Inclement Craft in Irving Park.</p></figcaption><span class="line"></span><div class="Figure-credit"><p>Pat Nabong/Sun-Times</p></div></div> </figure> </div> </div><p>Handspinning 101 is Inclement’s best-selling class, with tickets costing between $70 and $145. About 100 people have learned to make yarn on a drop spindle, since the space opened.</p><p>“You get to microdose personal growth. … You get to go through the steps of failing at something you want to be doing, and then there is that payoff,” Storm said.</p><p>Many participants are beginners, but Storm and Millard have been pleasantly surprised at the number of experts that show up to events.</p><p>In December, the founders started planning to bring in a factory-scale fiber mill, which they said would be Chicago's first in a century. They started a Kickstarter that month, with a goal of raising $95,000 for the down payment on the equipment. Inclement said the fiber mill would allow it to produce “gorgeous high quality blanks for folks who dye finished yarn,” stock its retail section and wholesale its goods to other businesses, according to the campaign.</p><p>“We went into the Kickstarter expecting a lot of momentum from business-to-business interactions … and it was totally the opposite. There was a lot of grassroots traction with end consumers who just wanted to purchase the product,” Storm said.</p><p>The <a class="Link" href="https://www.kickstarter.com/projects/inclementcraft/the-inclement-mill-rebuilding-chicago-yarn-manufacturing/description" target="_blank" >campaign</a> missed its goal, but raised over $20,000, which Storm said was a “very encouraging temperature check.” If a campaign doesn't meet its goal within the maximum time of 60 days, Kickstarter returns donors' money.</p><p>Plans for the mill are still in play, and they're gearing up “for a very exciting spring,” Storm said. Opening their own mill would allow them to be involved in every stage of yarn production.</p><p>“We get a lot of convenience [in today’s world],” Millard said. “But we don’t have as many excuses to do something tedious and frustrating with people you like.”</p><div class="RelatedList Enhancement" data-module data-align-center> <div class="RelatedList-title">Related</div> <ul class="RelatedList-items"> <li class="RelatedList-items-item"> <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/small-business/2026/01/15/shoppers-chicago-stationery-shops-atlas-paper-pencil-hobonichi-social-media-analog" >Looking for a pen? Shoppers overwhelm Chicago stationery shops as social media touts ‘return to analog’</a> </li> </ul> </div> <p></p>

entries.author: Sun-Times staff

entries.title: Rev. Jesse Jackson, civil rights leader and Chicago icon, dead at 84
entries.summary: <p></p><p>“I may be poor ...” began the call-and-response Rev. Jesse Jackson led in various forms before rapt audiences for more than half a century. “But I am ... <i>somebody!</i> I may be on welfare. But I am ... <i>somebody!</i> I may be in jail. But I am ... <i>somebody!</i> I may be uneducated, But I am ... <i>somebody.</i> I am Black. Beautiful. Proud. I must be respected. I must be protected. I am ... <i>somebody!</i>”</p><p>That, in essence, is the message Rev. Jackson devoted his life to championing — for Black people in general and himself in particular. From leading Rev. Martin Luther King Jr.’s open housing campaign in Chicago in 1964, through his close association with the great civil rights leader during the last three years of King’s life, to the tumultuous 1970s, when Jackson started what became the Rainbow PUSH Coalition, to the 1980s, when he ran the first viable presidential campaign by a Black candidate in the United States, to the 1990s, when he traveled the globe, to free hostages, advise leaders, join picket lines and lend his internationally famous name to often desperate causes. To his later years, when he settled into the role as a revered elder statesman of Black Chicago and an unceasing voice for social justice.</p><p>Rev. Jackson died at age 84 on Tuesday, his family said in a statement. He had been in declining health for a decade; in 2017 he announced he had been <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/2017/11/17/18375473/rev-jesse-jackson-announces-parkinson-s-diagnosis" >diagnosed with Parkinson’s disease</a> two years earlier, but last April revealed that it was actually misdiagnosed progressive supranuclear palsy, a condition also affecting bodily movements. He stepped down as president of PUSH in July 2023, citing health concerns. Rev. Jackson appeared onstage at the Democratic National Convention in Chicago in August 2024, when he was presented to the crowd after a video celebrating his life, but did not speak.</p><div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="Enhancement-item" data-crop=""> <figure class="Figure"><a class="AnchorLink" id="image-780000" name="image-780000"></a> <picture data-crop="medium"> <source type="image/webp" width="490" height="275" data-srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/459870a/2147483647/strip/true/crop/6122x3436+0+324/resize/490x275!/format/webp/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Ff8%2Fba%2F8b1db2dd47e29d644649723a99e9%2Fdnctu-082124-24.jpg 1x,https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/8e36895/2147483647/strip/true/crop/6122x3436+0+324/resize/980x550!/format/webp/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Ff8%2Fba%2F8b1db2dd47e29d644649723a99e9%2Fdnctu-082124-24.jpg 2x" data-lazy-load="true" srcset="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" /> <source width="490" height="275" data-srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/107b35d/2147483647/strip/true/crop/6122x3436+0+324/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Ff8%2Fba%2F8b1db2dd47e29d644649723a99e9%2Fdnctu-082124-24.jpg" data-lazy-load="true" srcset="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" /> <img class="Image" alt="Rev. Jesse Jackson joins the floor on the second day of the Democratic National Convention at the United Center in August 2024." srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/107b35d/2147483647/strip/true/crop/6122x3436+0+324/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Ff8%2Fba%2F8b1db2dd47e29d644649723a99e9%2Fdnctu-082124-24.jpg 1x,https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/a319efd/2147483647/strip/true/crop/6122x3436+0+324/resize/980x550!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Ff8%2Fba%2F8b1db2dd47e29d644649723a99e9%2Fdnctu-082124-24.jpg 2x" width="490" height="275" data-src="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/107b35d/2147483647/strip/true/crop/6122x3436+0+324/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Ff8%2Fba%2F8b1db2dd47e29d644649723a99e9%2Fdnctu-082124-24.jpg" data-lazy-load="true" src="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" > </picture> <div class="Figure-content"><figcaption class="Figure-caption"><p>Rev. Jesse Jackson joins the floor on the second day of the Democratic National Convention at the United Center in August 2024.</p></figcaption><span class="line"></span><div class="Figure-credit"><p>Anthony Vazquez/Sun-Times file</p></div></div> </figure> </div> </div><div class="RelatedList Enhancement" data-module data-align-center> <div class="RelatedList-title">Related</div> <ul class="RelatedList-items"> <li class="RelatedList-items-item"> <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/obituaries/2026/02/17/photos-jesse-jackson-through-the-years" >Photos: Jesse Jackson through the years</a> </li> </ul> </div> <p>If the legend of his mentor, Martin Luther King was simplified, almost beatified, by early death — a martyr at 39, an icon who had a dream — then the legacy of his eager protege was complicated by long life. Rev. Jesse Jackson was in the public eye for six decades, a tireless wielder of social pressure. He was respected and dismissed, inspiring adoration and disdain, a Chicago institution who left footprints on the world stage, an ardent advocate for civil rights whose attempts to wield political power himself were thwarted, and channeled into the power of protest, persuasion and complaint.</p><p>”Yet, there are doubts and criticisms raised about this complex man, a man characterized by ambiguity and contradiction,” the New York Times magazine wrote about him in 1972. “He is a brilliant speaker, a skilled mobilizer. He is also vain and self-seeking, a star, a man of great ambition, a man who, at times, uses the tricks of a demagogue.”</p><p>Which is another way to describe a powerful orator who inspired and uplifted millions of people, whether one-on-one or through the media he played skillfully around the world. In everything he did, Jackson was always pushing to be counted and make a difference. To be somebody.</p><div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="Enhancement-item" data-crop=""> <figure class="Figure"><a class="AnchorLink" id="image-b60000" name="image-b60000"></a> <picture data-crop="medium"> <source type="image/webp" width="490" height="275" data-srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/b8ce732/2147483647/strip/true/crop/2921x1639+0+154/resize/490x275!/format/webp/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F69%2F3a%2F2db94f2748d4a57eb3367bf73dca%2Fcupich-041517-08.jpeg 1x,https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/54e8d37/2147483647/strip/true/crop/2921x1639+0+154/resize/980x550!/format/webp/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F69%2F3a%2F2db94f2748d4a57eb3367bf73dca%2Fcupich-041517-08.jpeg 2x" data-lazy-load="true" srcset="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" /> <source width="490" height="275" data-srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/e87b46f/2147483647/strip/true/crop/2921x1639+0+154/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F69%2F3a%2F2db94f2748d4a57eb3367bf73dca%2Fcupich-041517-08.jpeg" data-lazy-load="true" srcset="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" /> <img class="Image" alt="Dominique Jones broke down in tears and hugged Rev. Jesse Jackson while talking about how her cousin, 17-year-old Stevie Jefferson, was shot to death on Jan. 4. Jones, Jackson and hundreds of people joined Cardinal Blase Cupich, Archbishop of Chicago, for a Walk For Peach and traced the Stations of the Cross through Englewood on Good Friday, April 14, 2017. " srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/e87b46f/2147483647/strip/true/crop/2921x1639+0+154/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F69%2F3a%2F2db94f2748d4a57eb3367bf73dca%2Fcupich-041517-08.jpeg 1x,https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/9b232fc/2147483647/strip/true/crop/2921x1639+0+154/resize/980x550!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F69%2F3a%2F2db94f2748d4a57eb3367bf73dca%2Fcupich-041517-08.jpeg 2x" width="490" height="275" data-src="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/e87b46f/2147483647/strip/true/crop/2921x1639+0+154/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F69%2F3a%2F2db94f2748d4a57eb3367bf73dca%2Fcupich-041517-08.jpeg" data-lazy-load="true" src="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" > </picture> <div class="Figure-content"><figcaption class="Figure-caption"><p>Dominique Jones breaks down in tears and hugs the Rev. Jesse Jackson while talking about how her cousin, 17-year-old Stevie Jefferson, was shot to death on Jan. 4. Jones, Jackson and hundreds of people joined Cardinal Blase Cupich for a Walk For Peace and traced the Stations of the Cross through Englewood on Good Friday, April 14, 2017.</p></figcaption><span class="line"></span><div class="Figure-credit"><p>Ashlee Rezin/Sun-Times file</p></div></div> </figure> </div> </div><p>He was born under highly unpromising circumstances, on Oct. 8, 1941 in Greenville, South Carolina, in a three-room, tin-roofed house without running water. His mother was an unwed 16-year-old high school student named Helen Burns. His father, Noah Robinson, was a married neighbor more than twice her age — 33 — with three stepchildren.</p><p>When Jesse was a toddler, his mother married Charles Jackson, who adopted Jesse when he was about 12. Charles Jackson worked as a janitor, and sometimes young Jesse would help him clean buildings.</p><p>It was a deeply segregated time and place. When baseball star Jackie Robinson came to Greenville for the NAACP, he wasn’t allowed to use the bathroom at the airport. Young Jesse was taunted for his stammer, which would return in moments of excitement later in life. His mother was his first adoring audience. She always told him, Rev. Jackson later recalled: “You’re going to be somebody. Just hold on.” </p><p>His calling came early.</p><p>“Jesse was an unusual kind of fella, even when he was just learning to talk,’’ Robinson remembered. ‘’He would say he’s going to be a preacher. He would say, ‘I’m going to lead people through the rivers of water.’‘’</p><h3>As a teen, Jackson arrives in Chicago</h3><p>Jackson was drawn to Chicago by an uncle, Henry Williams, who lived at 61st and Vernon and worked at the U.S. Postal Service’s Englewood station, but often returned south.</p><p>”He would travel back home in the summertime to visit,” Rev. Jackson wrote. “After his stay, we went with him to the station and it was so sad when the train would pull off ... how we desperately wanted to accompany him ... bound for Chicago.”</p><p>He got his wish at 15, when he was put on the train to Atlanta, fortified with his mother’s ham sandwiches, hard-boiled eggs, sweet potato pie and a jug of lemonade.</p><p>”God,” he thought, arriving at the 63rd Street station. “I am in Chicago.”</p><div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="Enhancement-item" data-crop=""> <figure class="Figure"><a class="AnchorLink" id="image-820000" name="image-820000"></a> <picture data-crop="medium"> <source type="image/webp" width="490" height="275" data-srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/a55b594/2147483647/strip/true/crop/2509x1408+0+796/resize/490x275!/format/webp/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Fa1%2F76%2Fd84cef154bee9ad48e68c3250db0%2Fdashiki-garment-0001a-4518.jpg 1x,https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/4c3d4a3/2147483647/strip/true/crop/2509x1408+0+796/resize/980x550!/format/webp/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Fa1%2F76%2Fd84cef154bee9ad48e68c3250db0%2Fdashiki-garment-0001a-4518.jpg 2x" data-lazy-load="true" srcset="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" /> <source width="490" height="275" data-srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/92800ba/2147483647/strip/true/crop/2509x1408+0+796/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Fa1%2F76%2Fd84cef154bee9ad48e68c3250db0%2Fdashiki-garment-0001a-4518.jpg"
